DIV1.P: APPIUS AND VIRGINIA. A TRAGEDY. BY JOHN WEBSTER.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: IS Appius sent for, that we may acquaint him
with the decree o'th' Senate?

SP.SPEAKER: Lictor
SP.L: He is, my Lord, and will attend
your Lordships presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Opp.
SP.L: Lictor, did you tell him that our businesse
was from the Senate?

SP.SPEAKER: Lict.
SP.L: I did, my Lord, and here he is at hand.
SP.STAGE: Enter Appius, his two Cozens and M. Clodius.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius
SP.L: My Lords, your pleasure?

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Appius, the Senate greet you well,
and by us do signifie unto you
that they have chosen you one of the Decemviti.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: My Lords, far be it from the thoughts
of so poor a Plebeian, as your unworthy servant
Appius, to soar so high: the dignity of so
eminent a place would require a person
of the best parts and blood in Rome.
My Lords, he that must steer at th' head of an
Empire, ought to be the Mirrour of the times
for Wisdome and for Policie, and therefore
I would beseech the Senate to elect one.
worthy of the place, and not to think of
one so unfit as Appius.

SP.SPEAKER: Min.
SP.L: My Lord, y Lord▪ you ally with your wits.
I have seen children oft eat sweet meats thus,
as fearfull to devoure them
you are wise and play the odest right
to make so many of our delight

SP.SPEAKER: Oppius.
SP.L: t yo must ow, what e have once concluded
cannot for any private mans affection
be slighted: take your choice then with best judgement
of these two proffers, either to accept
the place prop'd you, or be bnished Rome
immediately: Lictors e wa: we expe
you peedy reolution.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cozen.
SP.L: Noble cozen,
you wrong your selfe extremely to refuse
so Eminent a place.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cozen.
SP.L: It is a meanes
to raise your kindred. Who shall dare t'oppose
himselfe against our Family, when yonder
shall sit your power, and frowne?

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Or banist Rome!
I pray forbear a little. Marcus.

SP.SPEAKER: Marcus. Cl.
SP.L: Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: How dost thou like my cunning?

SP.SPEAKER: Marcus. Cl.
SP.L: I protest
I was be-agued, fearing let the Senate
should have accepted at your fain'd refusall.
See how your kindred and your friends are mustr'd
to warme them at your sun-shine. Were you now
in prison, or arraign'd before the Senate
for some suspect of treason, all these swallowes
would flie your stormy winter, not one ing:
their Musick is the Summer and the Spring.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Thou observet shrewdly: well, e fit them ort.
I must be one of the Decemvir,
or banish't Rome. Banish laugh, my trusty Marcus,
I am inforc't to my ambition.
I have heard of cunning footmen that have worne
shooes made of lead some ten dayes fore a race
to give them nimble and more active feet:
so great men should, that eminent place,
load themselves with excuse and aint denyll,
that they with more speed may performe the trial:
Marke his humility saies one; how far
his dreames are from ambition▪ aies another:
he would not shew his Eloquence, lest that
should draw him into office: and a third
is meditating on some thrifty suite
to beg 'fore dinner. Had I as many hands
as had Briarius, I'de extend them all
to catch this office; 'twas my sleeps disturber,
my dyets ill digestion, my melancholy
past physicks cure.

SP.SPEAKER: Marcus.
SP.L: The Senators returne.

SP.SPEAKER: Minu.
SP.L: My Lord, your answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: To obey my Lord, and to know how to rule
doe differ much: to obey by nature comes,
but to command by long experience.
Never were great men in so eminent place
without their shadowes. Envy will attend
on greatnesse till this generall frame takes end.
'Twixt these extreames of state and banishment,
my minde hath held long conflict, and at last
I thus returne my answer, noble friends,
we now must part, necessity of State
compells it so.
I must inhabit, now a place unknowne,
you see't compels me leave you. Fare you well.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cozen.
SP.L: To banishment, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: I am given up
to a long travell full of fear and danger,
to waste the day in sweat, and the cold night
in a most desolate contemplation,
banisht from all my kindred and my friends,
yea banisht from my selfe; for I accept
this honourable calling.

SP.SPEAKER: Minu.
SP.L: Worthy Appius,
the gods conduct you hither: Lictors, His robes.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Cozen.
SP.L: We are made for ever, noble kinsman,
'twas but to fright us.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: But my loving kinsmen,
mistake me not, for what I spake was true,
bear witnesse all the gods: I told you first,
I was to inhabit in a place unknown;
'tis very certaine, for this reverend seat
receives me as a pupill, rather gives
ornament to the person, then our person
the least of grace to it. I shewed you next
I am to travell; 'tis a certaine truth:
Look by how much the labour of the minde
exceeds the bodies, so far am I ound
with paine and industry, beyond the toyle
of those that sweat in warre, beyond the toyle
of any Artisan, pale cheeks, and sunk eyes,
a head with watching dizied, and a haire
turn'd white in youth, all these at a dear rate.
we purchase speedily that tend a State.
I told you I must leave you, 'tis most true.
Henceforth the face of a Barbarian
and yours shall be all one, henceforth Ile know you
but only by your vertue: brother or father
in dishonest suite shall be to me
as is the branded slave. Justice should have
no kindred, friends, nor foes, nor hate, nor love,
as free from passion as the gods above.
I was your friend and kinsman, now your Judge,
and whilst I hold the scales, a downy feather
shall as soone turne them as a masse of Pearle
or Diamonds.

SP.SPEAKER: Marcus.
SP.L: Excellent, excellent Lapwing,
there's other stuffe closed in that subtle brest.
He sings and beats his wings far from his nest.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: So Gentlemen, I take it, here takes end
your businesse; my acquaintance, fare you well.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Cozen.
SP.L: Heres a quick change, who did expect this cloud?
Thus men when they grow great doe strait grow proud.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Now to our present businesse at the camp:
the army that doth winter 'fore Agidon,
is much distrest we heare: Minutius,
you with the levies and the little corne
this present dearth will yield, are speedily
to hasten thither, so to appease the minde
of the intemperate souldier.

SP.SPEAKER: Minu:
SP.L: I am ready
the levies doe attend me, our Lieutenant
send on our Troopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius:
SP.L: Farewell Minutius.
the gods goe with you, and be still at hand
to adde a triumph to your bold command.

SP.SPEAKER: Numitor.
SP.L: Noble Icilius. welcome, teach your selfe
a older freedome here, for by our love
your suite to my faire Neece doth parallell
her kindreds wishes. There's not in all Rome
a man that is by honour more approv'd
nor worthier, were you poore, to be belov'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: You give me (noble Lord) that character
which I cood never yet read in my selfe:
but from your censure shall I take much care
to adorne it with the fairest ornaments
of unambitious vertue: here I hold
my honorable patterne, one whose minde
appeares more like a ceremonious chappell
full of sweet musick, then a thronging presence.
I am confirm'd, the court doth make some shew
fairer then else they would doe; but her port
being simple vertue, beautifies the court,

SP.SPEAKER: Virginia.
SP.L: It is a flattery (my Lord)
you breath upon me, and it shewes much like
the borrowed painting which some Ladies use,
it is not to continue many dayes;
my wedding garments will outweare this praise.

SP.SPEAKER: Numitor.
SP.L: Thus Ladies still foretell the funerall
of their Lords kindnesse.
But my Lord, what newes?
SP.STAGE: Enter a Servant, whispers Icilius in the eare.

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: Virginius, my Lord, your noble brother
disguis'd in dust and sweat, is new arriv'd
within the City: troopes of artisans
follow his panting horse, and with a strange
confused noyse, partly with joy to see him,
partly with fear for what his hast portends,
they shew as if a sudden mutiny
orespread the City.

SP.SPEAKER: Numitor.
SP.L: Cozen take your chamber.
What businesse from the camp?

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: Sure Sir it beares
the forme of some great danger, for his horse
bloody with spurring, shewes as if he came
from forth a battel: never did you see
'mongst quailes or cocks in fight a bloodier Heele,
then that your brother strikes with. In this forme
of orespent horseman, having as it seemes,
with the distracting of his newes, forgot
house, friends, or change of raiment, he is gone
to th'Senate house.

SP.SPEAKER: Numitor.
SP.L: Now the gods bring us safety,
the face of this is cloudy, let us haste
to'th Senate house, and there enquire how neare
the body moves of this our threatned fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Cl:
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Thor troublest me.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: My hand's as ready arm'd to work your peace
as my tongue bold to inquire your diseontents.
Good my Lord hear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: I am at much variance
within my selfe, there's discord in my blood,
my powers are all in combat, I have nothing
left but sedition in me.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: Trust my bosom
to be the closet of your private griefs.
Beleeve me, I am uncranied.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: May I trust thee?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Clodius.
SP.L: As the firme centre to indure the burden
of your light soot, as you would trust the poles
to bear on them this airy cannopy,
and not to fear their shrinking. I am strong,
fixt and unshaking.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Art thou? Then thine ever: I love.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Clodius.
SP.L: Ha ha he.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Can this my ponderous secresie
be in thine ear so light? seemes my disturbance
worthy such scorne that thou deridest my griefs?
Beleeve me, Clodius, I am not a twig
that every gust can shake, but 'tis a tempest
that must be able to use violence
on my grown branches. Wherefore laugh'st thou then?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Clodius.
SP.L: Not that y'are mov'd, it makes me smile in scorne
that wise men cannot understand themselves,
nor know their own prov'd greatnesse. Clodius laughes not
to think you love, but that you are so hopelesse
not to presume to injoy whom you affect.
What's she in Rome your greatnesse cannot awe
or your rich purse purchase? Promises and thrats
are statemens Lictors to arrest such pleasures
as they would bring within their strict commands;
why should my Lord droop, or deject his eye?
can you command Rome, and not countermand
a womans weaknesse? Let your Grce
your purse and power on me. I'le prostrate you.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Ask both and lavish them to purchase ie
the rich fee-simple of Virginia's heart.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Clodius.
SP.L: Virginia's!

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Hers.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Clodius.
SP.L: I have already found
an easie path which you may safely tread,
yet no man trace you.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Thou art my comforter.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Clodius.
SP.L: Her father's busied in our forreign wars,
and there hath chief imployment; all their pay
must your discretion scantle: keep it back,
restraine it in the common Treasury.
Thus may a states-man'gainst a souldier stand,
to keep his purse weak, whil'st you arme his hand.
Her father thus kept low, gifts and rewards
will tempt the maide the sooner; nay haply draw
the father in to plead in your behalfe.
But should these aile, then siege her Virgin Tower
with too prevailing engines, feare and power.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Go then and prove a speeding advocate;
Arme thee with all our bounty, oratory,
variety of promise.

SP.SPEAKER: Valerius.
SP.L: L. Appius, the Decemvirate intreat
your voice in this dayes Senate. Old Virginius
craves audience from the camp with earnest suite
for quick dispatch.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: We will attend the Senate.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius,
SP.L: Be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Opius.
SP.L: We sent to you to assist us in this counsell
touching the expeditions of our war.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Ours is a willing presence to the trouble
of all State cares. Admit him from the camp.

SP.SPEAKER: Opius.
SP.L: Speak the camps will.

SP.SPEAKER: Virginius.
SP.L: The camp wants money, we have store of knocks,
and wounds Gods plnty, but we have no pay,
this three moneths did we never house our heads,
but in yon great star-chamber; never bedded
but in the cold field-beds, our vittaile failes us,
yet meet with no supply; we're fairly promis'd,
but souldiers cannot feed on promises;
all our provant, apparell's torne to rags,
and our Munition fails us: Will you send us
to fight for Rome like beggars? Noble Gentlemen,
are you the high State of Decemviri,
that have those things in mannage? Pity us,
for we have need on't. Let not your delays
be cold to us, whose bloods have oft been heated
to gaine you fame and riches. Prove not to us
(being our friends) worse foes then we fight with:
Let's not be starv'd in kindnesse. Sleep you now
upon the bench, when your deaf ears should listen
unto the wretchlesse clamours of the poor?
Then would I had my Drums here, they might rattle,
and rowse you to attendance. Most grave Fathers,
shew your selves worthy stewards to our Mother
fair Rome, to whom we are no bastard sons,
though we be souldiers. She hath in her store
food to maintain life in the Camp, as wel
as surfet for the City. Do not save
the foe a labour; send us some supply,
lest ere they kill us, we by famine die.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Shall I (my Lords) give answer to this souldier?

SP.SPEAKER: Opius.
SP.L: Be you the Cities voyce.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Virginius, we would have you thus possess'd,
we sit not here to be prescib'd and taught,
nor to have any suter give us limit,
whose power admits no curb. Next know, Virginius,
the Camp's our servant, and must be dispos'd,
controul'd and us'd by us, that have the strength
to knit it or dissolve it. When we please
out of our Princely grace and clemency
to look upon your wants, it may be then
we shall redress them: But till then, it fits not
that any petty fellow wag'd by us
should have a tongue found here before a Bench
of such grave Auditours. Further,—

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Pray give me leave,
Not here? pray Appius, is not this the Judgment seat?
Where should a poor mans cause be heard but here?
To you the Statists of long flourishing Rome,
to you I call, If you have charity,
if you be humane, and not quite giv'n ore
to Furs and Metall, if you be Romans,
if you have any souldiers bloud at all
flow in your veins, help with your able arms
to prop a sinking camp, an infinite
of fair Rome's sons, cold, weak, hungry, and clothles,
would feed upon your surfet. Will you save them,
or shall they perish?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: What we will, we will,
be that your answer: perhaps at further leasure
We'l help you, not your merit but our pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: I will not curse thee, Appius, but I wish
thou wert i'th' camp amongst the Mutineers
to tell my answers, not to trouble me.
Make you us dogs, yet not allow us bones?
Oh what are souldiers come too! Shall your camp.
the strength of all your peace, and the iron wall
that rings this Pomp in from invasive steel;
shall that decay? Then let the forrain fires
climb o're these buildings; let the sword and slaughter
chase the gown'd Senate through the streets of Rome.
to double dye their robes in Scarlet; let
the enemies stript arm have his crimson'd brawns
up to the elbowes in your traiterous bloud;
Let Ianus Temple be devolv'd, your Treasures
ript up to pay the common adversaryes
with our due wages. Do you look for lesse?
the rottenness of this misgovern'd State
must grow to some Disease, incurable
save with a sack or slaughter.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Y'are too bold.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Know you our extremities?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: We do.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: And will not help them?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: When?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Hereafter.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Hereafter? when so many gallant spirits
that yet may stand betwixt you and destruction,
are sunk in death? Hereafter? when disorder
hath swallowed all our Forces?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: We'l hear no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Opius.
SP.L: Peace, fellow peace, know the Decemviri,
and their Authority; we shall commit you else.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Do so, and I shall thank you; be relieved
and have a strong house o're me, fear no Alarmes
given in the night by any quick perdue.
Your Guilty in the City feeds more dainty
then doth your Generall. 'Tis a better Office
to be an under Keeper then a Captain;
The gods of Rome amend it.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Break up the Senate.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: And shall I have no answer?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: So farewel.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: What Slave would be a soldier to be censured
by such as ne'er saw danger? To have out pay,
our worths and merits allano'd in the scale
of base moth-eaten peace. I have had wounds
would have made all this Bench faint and look pale
but to behold them searcht. They lay their heads
on their soft pillow, pore upon then bags,
grow fat with laziness and resty .
And us that stand betwixt them and disaster
they will not spare a Drachma. O my souldiers,
before you want, I'l sell my smal possessions
even to my skin to help you, Plate and Jewels
all shall be yours. Men that are men indeed,
the earth shal find, the Sun and air must feed.

SP.SPEAKER: Numitor.
SP.L: Your daughter, noble brother, heating late
of your arrvial from the Camp, most humbly
prostrates her filial Duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Daughter rise.
And brother I am only rich in her,
and in your love, link' with the honour'd friendship
of those fair Romane Lords. For you Icilius,
I hear I must adopt you with the title
of a new son; you are Virginia's chief,
and I am proud she hath built her fair election
Upon such store of vertues. May you grow,
although a Cities child, to know a souldier
and rate him to his merit.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Noble father,
(for henceforth I shal onely use that name)
Our meeting was to urge you to the processe
of our fair contract.

SP.SPEAKER: Virgin.
SP.L: Witnesse Gentlemen,
here I give up a fathers interest,
but not a fathers love, that I wil ever
wear next my heart, for was born with her
d growes still with my age.

SP.SPEAKER: Numitor.
SP.L: receive her: witnesse noble Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Valer.
SP.L: With all my heart. I would Icilius could do as much
for me; but Rome affords not such another Virginia.

SP.SPEAKER: Virgin.
SP.L: I am my fathers daughter, and by him
I must be swaid in all things.

SP.SPEAKER: Num.
SP.L: Brother, this happy Contract asks a Feast,
as a thing due to such solemnities.
It shall be at my house, where we this night
will sport away some hours.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: I must to horse.

SP.SPEAKER: Numitor.
SP.L: What, ride to night?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Must see the Camp to night.
'Tis full of trouble and destracted fears,
and may grow mutinous. I am bent to ride.

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: To night?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: I am ingag'd: short farwels now must serve,
the universal businesse calls me hence,
that toucheth a whole people. Rome, I fear,
thou wilt pay use for what thou dost forbear.

SP.STAGE: Enter Clown whispering Virginia, after her M. Clodius with presents.

SP.SPEAKER: Virginia
SP.L: SIrrah, go tell Calpharina, I am walking
to take the air: intreat her company.
Say I attend her coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Corbulo
SP.P: Madam, I shall: but if you could walk abroad, and get an Heir, it were better, for your father hath a fair revenue, and never a son to inherit.

SP.SPEAKER: Virginia
SP.L: You are, sirrah—

SP.SPEAKER: Corbulo
SP.P: Yes I am sirrah: but not the party that is born to do that; though I have no Lorships, yet I have so much manners to give my betters place.

SP.SPEAKER: Virginia
SP.L: Whom mean you by your betters?

SP.SPEAKER: Corbulo
SP.P: I hope I have learnt to know the three degrees of compa∣rison: for though I be bonus, and you melior as well as mulier; yet my Lord Icilius is optimus.

SP.SPEAKER: Virginia
SP.L: I see there's nothing in such private done,
but you must inquire after.

SP.SPEAKER: Corbulo
SP.P: And can you blame us (Madam) to long for the merry day, as you do for the merry night?

SP.SPEAKER: Virginia.
SP.L: Will you be gone sir? (nd.

SP.SPEAKER: Corbula.
SP.L: Oh yes, to my Lady . I remember my er-

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: My father's wondrous , and withall
with a supprest rage left his house displeas'd,
and so in post is hurried to the camp:
it sads me much; to expell which melancholy,
I have sent for company.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: This opportunity was illy waited,
it is the best part of a politician
when he would compasse ought to fame his industry
wisely to waite the advantage of the houres,
his happie minutes are not alwayes present.
Expresse your greatest art, Virginia hears you,

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: Oh I conceive the occasion of this harmony.
Icilius sent it, I must thank his kindnesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Let not Virginia wate her contemplation
so high, to call this visit an intrusion;
for when she understands I tooke my message
from one that did compose it with affection,
I know she will not only extend pardon,
but grace it with her favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: You mediate excuse for courtesies,
as if I were so of civiy,
not to esteeme it worthy of my thanks;
assure your selfe I could be longer patient
to hear my eares so feasted.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Ioyne all your voyces till you make the aire
proud to usurpe your nos, and to please her
with a sweet eccho; serve Virginias pleasure.
As you have been so full of gentlenesse
to heare with patience what was brought to serve you
so hearken with your usuall clemency
o the relation of a lovers sufferings:
your figure still does revell in his dreames,
he banquets on your memory, yet findes
not thoughts enough to satisfie his wishes,
as if Virginia had compos'd his heart,
and fills it with her beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: I see he is a miser in his wishes,
and thinks he never has enough of that
which onely he possesses: but to give
his wishes satisfaction, let him know
his heart and mine do so near together,
that hourely they converse, and guard each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Is faire Virginia confident she knowes
her favour dwels with the same man I plead for?

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: —Unto Icilius.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Worthy faire one,
I would not wrong your worth so to employ
my language for a man so much beneath
the merit of your beauty: he I plead for
has power to make your beauty populous,
your frowne shall awe the world, and in your smile
great Rome shall build her happinesse;
honour and wealth shall not be stil'd companions,
but servants to your pleasure.
Then shall Icilius (but a refin'd Citizen)
boast your affection, when Lord Appius loves you.

SP.SPEAKER: Vir.
SP.L: Blesse his great Lordship, I was much mistaken,
let thy Lord know, thou Advocate of lust,
all the intentions of that youth are honourable,
whil'st his are fill'd with sensuality.
And for a finall resolution know,
our hearts in love like twins alike shall grow.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Had I a wife, or daughter that could please him
I would devote her to him, but I must
shadow this scorne, and sooth him still in lust.
What newes yet of Virginius returne?
Not any.
O the misery of Souldiers!
They doubly starve us with faire promises.
We spread the earth like haile, or new reapt corne
in this fierce famine; and yet patiently
make our obedience the confined ile
that starves us:
Souldiers, let us draw our swords
while we have strength to use them.
'Tis a motion
which nature and necessity commands.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Y'are of Virginius Regiment.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: We are.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Why doe you swarme in troopes thus? to your quarter.
Is our command growne idle? to your trench.
Come I'le divide you, this your conference
is not without suspect of mutiny.
Souldiers, shall I relate the grievances.
of the whole Regiment.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Boldly.
Then thus my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Come, I will not hear thee,
Sir you shall:
Sound all the Drums and Trumpets in the camp,
to drowne my utterance, yet above them all
I'le rear our just complaint. Stir not my Lord,
I vow you are not safe if you but move
a sinew till you heare us.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Well sir, command us: you are the Generall.
No my Lord, not I,
I am almost starved; I wake in the wet trench,
loaded with more cold iron then a Jaile
would give a murderer, while the Generall
sleeps in a field bed, and to mock our hunger
feeds us with scent of the most curious fare
that makes his tables crack, our pay detained
by those that are our Leaders: and at once
we in this sad, and unprepared plight,
with the Enemy, and Famine daily sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Doe you threaten us?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Sir you shall hear him out.
You send us whips, and iron manackles,
and shackles plenty, but the devill a coine.
Would you would teach us that caniball trick, my Lord,
which some rich men 'ith' City oft doe use:
shall's one devoure another?

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Will you hear me?
O Rome th'art growne a most unnaturall mother,
to those have held thee by the golden locks
from sinking into ruine; Romulus
was fed by a she wolfe, but now our wolves
instead of feeding us devoure our flesh,
carouse our blood, yet are not drunk with it,
for three parts of 't is water.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Your Captaine,
noble Virginius is sent Rome,
for ease of all your grievances.
'Tis false.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: I, 'Tis false.
Hee's stolne away from's, never to returne,
and now his age will suffer him no more
deale on the Enemy, belike hee'l rne
an usurer, and in the City aire
cut poore mens throats at home sitting in's chaire.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: You wrong one of the honorablest Commanders.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Honorable Commander?
Commander? I my Lord, there goes the thrist
in victories, the Generall and Commanders
share all the honour as they share the spoile;
but in our overthrowes, where lies the blame?
the common souldiers fault, ours is the shame.
What is the reason that being so far distant
from the affrighted enemy? wee lie
'ith' open field, subject to the sick humors
of heaven and earth: unlesse you cood bestow
two summers of us? shall I tell you truth,
You account the expence of Ingines, and of swords,
of horses and of armor dearer far,
then souldiers lives.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Now by the gods you doe.
Observe you not the ravens and the crowes
have left the City surfet, and with us
they make full banquets. Come you birds of death,
and fill your greedy croppes with humane flesh;
then to the City flie, disgorge it there
before the Senate, and from thence arise
a plague to choake all Rome. Omnes. And all the Suburbs▪

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Upon a souldiers word, bold Gentlemen,
I expect every houre Virginius
to bring fresh comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Whom? Virginius?
Now by the gods, if ever he returne,
wee'le drag him to the slaughter by his locks,
turned white with riot and incontinence,
and leave a president to all the world,
how Captaines use their souldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: See, hee's returned▪
Virginius, you are not safe, retire,
your troopes are mutinous, we are begirt
with Enemies more daring, and more fierce,
then is the common foe.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: My Troopes, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Your life is threatned by these desperate men,
betake you to your horse.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: My noble Lord,
I never yet poiest to teach the art
of ying. , out troopes grown mutinous?
he dares not look on me with half a
that spread this wildfire. Where is our Lieutenant?

SP.SPEAKER: Val.
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Sirrah, order our companies.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: What do you mean, my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Take air a little, they have heated me.
Sirrah, i'st you will mutiny?
Not I Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Is your gall burst, you Traitor?
The gods defend Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Or is your stomack sea sick, doth it rise?
I'l make a passage for it.
Noble Captain, I'l dye beneath your foot.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: You rough porcupine, ha.
do you bristle, do you shoot your quils you rogue?
They have no points to hurt you, noble Captain.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Wast you (my nimble shaver) that would whet
your sword 'gainst your Commanders throat, you sirrah?
My Lord I never dream't on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Slaves and cowards,
what are you cholerick now? by the gods
the way to purge it were to let you blood.
I am i'th' center of you, and I'l make
the proudest of you teach the Aspen leaf
to tremble, when I breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: A strange Conversion.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Advance your pikes. The word,

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Advance your pikes.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: See noble Lord these are no Mutineers,
these are obedient souldiers, civil men:
You shal command these, if your Lordship please,
to fil a ditch up with their slaughtered bodies,
that with more ease you may assault some Town.
So now lay down your Arms. Villains and Traitors,
I here cashier you. Hence from me my poison,
not worthy of our Discipline: Go beg,
go beg, you mutinous rogues, brag of the service
you ne'er durst look on; it were charity
to hang you, for my mind gives, y'are reserv'd
to rob poor market women.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: O Viginius.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: I do beseech you to confirm my sentence,
as you respect me. I will stand my self
for the whole Regiment, and safer far
in mine owne single valour, then begirt
with cowards and with traitors.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: O my Lord, you are too severe.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Now by the gods, my Lord,
you know no discipline, to pitie them.
Pretious divells? no sooner my back turn'd,
but presently to mutinie?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes:
SP.L: dear Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Refuse me if such traiterous rogues
would not confound an Army. When doe you march?
when doe you march, gentlemen?
My Lord, wee'l starve first,
wee'le hang first, by the gods, doe any thing
ere wee'le forsake you.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Good Virginius,
limit your passion.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Sir, you may take my place,
not my just anger from me: these are they
have bred a dearth i'th' campe: I'le wish our foes
no greater plague then to have their company:
show but among them all so many scars
as stick upon this flesh, I'le pardon them.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: How now, my Lord, breathlesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: By your favour. I ha said.
Mischiefs confound me if I could not wish
my youth renewed againe, with all her sollies,
onely to'ave breath enough to raile against
these—'Tis too short.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: See Gentlemen, what strange distraction
your falling off from duty hath begot
in this most noble souldier: You may live
the meanest of you to command a Troope,
and then in others youle correct those faults,
which in your selves you cherisht, every Captain
beares in his private government that forme,
which Kings should ore their Subjects, and to them
should be the like obedient. We confesse
you have been distrest: but can you justly challenge
any commander that hath surfeted,
while that your food was limited? You cannot.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: My Lord, I have shared with them an equall for▪
hunger, and cold, marcht thorough watery fens, tune,
borne as great burdens as the pioneer,
when scarce the ground would bear me.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Good my Lord, give us leave to proceed;
the punishment your Captaine hath inflicted
is not sufficient; for it cannot bring
any example to succeeding
of pennance worth your faulting: happily
it may in you beget a certaine shame;
But it will in others a strong hope
of the like lenity. Yet gentlemen,
you have in one thing given me such a taste
of your obedience; when the fire was raised
of fierce sedition, and the cheeke was swolne
to sound the fatall Trumpet, then the sight
of this your worthy Captaine did disperse
all those unfruitfull humours, and even then
convert you from feirce Tigers to stayed men:
we therefore pardon you, and doe restore
your Captaine to you, you unto your Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: The gods requite you, noble Generall.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: My Lord, my Lord:

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Your pardon noble Captaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Well, you are the Generall, and the fault is quit,
a souldiers teares, an elder brothers wit
have little falt in them, nor doe they season
things worth observing, for their want of reason.
Take up your armes and use them, doe I pray,
ere long youle take your to run away.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: And what supply from Rome?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Good store of corne.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: What entertainment there?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Most honourable,
especially by the Lord Appius.
There is great hope that Appius will grow
the souldiers patron: with what vehemency
he urg'd our wants, and with what expedition
he hasted the supplies, it is almost
iredible. There's promis'd to the souldier
besides their corne a bounteous donative;
but 'tis not certaine yet when't shall be paid.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: How for your owne particular?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: My Lord,
I was not enterd fully two pikes length
into the Senate, but they all stood bare,
and each man offer'd me his seat: The businesse
for which I went dispatcht, what guifts, what favours
were done me, your good Lordship shall not hear,
for you would wonder at them, onely this,
'twould make a man fight up to'th' neck in blood,
to think how nobly he shall be received
when he returnes to'th' City.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: 'Tis well,
give order the provision be divided
and sent to every quarter.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Sir, it shall.
Thus men must flight their wrongs, or else conceal them,
when generall safety wills us not reveale them.
SP.STAGE: Enter two Petitioners at one doore, at the other M. Clodius.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Petit.
SP.L: Pray is your Lord at leasure?

SP.SPEAKER: M. Clodius.
SP.L: What is your suite?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Pet.
SP.L: To accept this poore Petition which makes knowne,
my many wrongs in which I crave his Justice,
and upright sentence to support my cause,
which else is trod downe by oppression.

SP.SPEAKER: M. Clodius.
SP.L: My Lords hand is the prop of Innocence,
and if your cause be worthy his supportance
it cannot fall.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Petitioner.
SP.L: The gods of Rome protect him.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: What, is your paper too petitionary?

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Petit.
SP.L: It leanes upon the Justice of the Judge,
your noble Lord, the very stay of Rome.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: And surer basis, for a poore mans cause,
she cannot yeeld. Your papers I'le deliver,
and when my Lord ascends the Judgement seate,
you shall find gracious comfort.

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: Where's your Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: Icilius? faire Virginia's late betroth'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: Your eares, I hope, you have not forfeited,
that you returne no answer. Where's your Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: At's studie.

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: I desire admittance to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: Please you attend, I'le know his Lordships pleasure.
Icilius? I pray heaven she have not blab'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: Attend? a petty Lawyer t'other day,
glad of a fee, but cal'd to eminent place,
even to his betters, now the word's, Attend.
This gowned office, what a breadth it bears?
how many tempests waite upon his frowne?

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: All the petitioners withdraw. L. Appius
must have this place more private▪ as a favour,
reserv'd for you, Icilius. Here's my Lord.
SP.STAGE: Enter Appius with Lictors afors him.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Be gone, this place is only spar'd for us,
and you Icilius. Now your business.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: May I speak it freely?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: We have suffering ears,
A heart the sofest downe may penetrate.
Proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: We are private, Pray your courtefie.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: My duty.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Leave that to th' publick eye
of Rome, and of Romes people. Clodius there.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Place me a second Chaire; that done,
remove your self. So now, your absence Clodius.
Icilius sit, this grace we make not common
unto the noblest Romane, but to you
our love affords it freely. Now your suit?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: It is, you would be kind unto the Camp.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Wherein, Icilius, doth the Camp touch thee?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Thus: Old Virginius, now my father in Law,
kept from the publick pay, consumes himself,
sels his Revenues, turnes his plate to coyn,
to wage his souldiers, and supply the Camp,
wasting that useful substance which indeed
should rise to me, as my Virginia's Dowry.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: We meet that opposition thus Icilius.
The Camps supplies doth not consist in us,
but those that keep the common Treasury;
speak or intreat we may, but not command.
But Sir, I wonder, you so brave a Youth,
son to a thrifty Romane, should ally you,
and knit your strong armes to such falling branches;
which rather in their ruine will bear down
your strength, then you support their rottenness.
Be swayed by me, fly from that ruinous house.
whose fall may crush you; and contract with mine,
whose bases are of Marble, deeply fixt
to uger all gusts and impending stormes.
Ca off that beggars daughter, poor Virginia,
whose dowry and beauty, I'l see trebled both,
in one lly'd to me. Smile you Icilius?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: My Lord, my Lord, think you, I can imagine
your close and sparing hand can be profuse
to give that man a Palace, whom you late
deny'd a cottage? Will you from your own coffers
grant me a treble Dowry, yet interpose me
a poor third from the common Treasury?
You must move me by possibilities,
for I have brains; give first your hand and Seal,
that old Virginius shall receive his pay
both for himself and souldiers, and that done,
I shall perhaps be soon induc'd to think,
that you who with such willingness did that—

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Is my Love mispriz'd?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Not to Virginia.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Virginia?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Yes Virginia, Lustful Lord.
I did but trace your cunning all this while.
You would bestow me on some Appian Trull,
and for that dross to cheat me of my Gold;
for this the Camp pines, and the City smarts.
All Rome fares worse for thy incontinence.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Mine boy?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Thine Judg. This hand hath intercepted
thy Letters, and perus'd thy tempting guests,
these ears have heard thy amorous passions, wretch,
these eyes beheld thy treacherous name subscrib'd.
A Judg, a Divel.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Come I'hear no more.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Sit still, or by the powerful Gods of Rome
I'l nail thee to the Chair. But suffer me,
I'l offend nothing but thine ears.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Our Secretary.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Tempt not a Lovers fury, if thou dost
now by my vow, insculpt in heaven, I'l send thee.—

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: You see I am patient.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: But withal revengeless.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: So, say on.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Hope not of any grace, or the least favour,
I am so covetous of Virginia's love,
I cannot spare thee the least look, glance, touch.
Divide one bare imaginary thought
into a thousand, thousand parts, and that
I'l not afford thee.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Thou shalt not.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Nay, I will not.
Hadst thou a Judges place above those Judges
that judg all souls, having power to sentence me,
I would not bribe thee, no not with one hair
from her fair temples.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Thou shouldst not.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Nay, I would not.
Think not her Beauty shall have leave to crown
thy lustfull hopes with the least spark of blisse,
or have thine ears charm'd with the ravishing sound
even of her harshest phrase.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: I will not.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Nay, thou shalt not.
Shee's mine, my soul is crownd in her desire,
to her I'ld travell through a land of fire.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Now have you done?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: I have spoke my thoughts.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Then will thy fury give me leave to speak?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: I pray say on.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Icilius, I must chide you, and withall
tell you, your rashnesse hath made forfeiture
even of your precious life, which wee esteeme
too deer to call in question. I I wisht you
of my allyance, graft into my blood,
condemn you me for that? Oh see the rashnesse
and blind misprision of youth!
As for the Maid Virginia, wee are far
even in least thought from her; and for those Letters,
Tokens and Presents, wee acknowledg none.
Alas, though great in place, wee are not gods.
If any false impostor hath usurpt
our hand or greatnesse in his own behoof,
can wee help that? Icilius, there's our hand,
your rashnesse we remit; let's have hereafter
your love and best opinion. For your suit,
repair to us at both our better leisures,
wee'l breathe in it new life.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: I crave your don.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Granted ere crav'd, my good Icilius.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: —Morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: It is no more indeed. Morrow Icilius.
If any of our servants wait, without,
command them in.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: I shall.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Our Secretary,
we have use for him. Icilius, send him hither.
Again good morrow.
Go to thy death, thy life is doom'd and cast.
Appius be circumspect, and be not rash
in blood as th'art in lust: Be murderous stil,
but when thou strik'st, with unseen weapons kill.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: My Honourable Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Deride me, dog?

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: Who hath stirr'd up this tempest in your brow?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Not you? Fie, you?

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: All you Panthean Gods,
confound me, if my soul be accessary
to your distractions.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: To send a ruffian higher,
even to my closet, first, to brave my Greatness,
play with my beard, revile me, taunt me, hisse me;
nay after all these deep disparagements,
threat me with steel, and menace me unarm'd,
to nail me to my seat, if I but mov'd:
all these are slight, slight toyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: Icilius do this?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Ruffian Icilius, he that in the front
of a smooth Citizen, bears the rugged soul
of a most base Bandetto.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: He shall die for't.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Be not too rash.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: Were there no more men to support great Rome,
even falling Rome should perish, ere he stand:
I'l after him, and kill him.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Stay, I charge thee.
Lend me a patient ear; To right our wrongs,
we must not menace with a publick hand;
we stand in the worlds eye, and shall be taxt
of the least violence, where we revenge:
We should smile smoothest where our hate's most deep,
and when our spleen's broad waking, seem to sleep.
Let the young man play still upon the bit,
till we have brought and train'd him to our lure;
Great men should strike but once, and then strike sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: Love you Virginia still?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Do I still live?

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: Then she's your own. Virginius is, you say,
still in the Camp.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: True.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: Now in his absence will I claim Virginia
to be the daughter of a bond woman,
and slave to me; to prove which, I'l produce
firme proofs, notes probable, sound Witnesses;
then having with your Lictors summond her,
I'l bring the cause before your Judgement Seat,
where, upon my infallid evidence,
you may pronounce the sentence on my side,
and she become your Strumpet not your Bride.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Thou hast a copius brain, but how in this
shall we dispose Icilius?

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: If he spurne
clap him up close, there's wayes to charm his spleen.
By this no scandal can redound to you;
the Cause is mine; you but the Sentencer
upon that evidence which I shall bring.
The business is, to 'ave Warrants by Arrest.
to answer such things at the Judgment Bar
as can be laid against her; Ere her friends
can be assembled, ere her self can study
her answer or scarce know her cause of summons
to descant on the matter, Appius may
examine, try, and doom Virginia.
But all this must be sudden.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Thou art born
to mount me high above Icilius scorn.
I'l leave it to thy manage.

SP.SPEAKER: Corbulo.
SP.L: WHat was that you said, Nurse?

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.L: Why, I did say thou must bestir thy selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Corbulo.
SP.P: I warrant you I can bestir my stumps as soon as ano∣ther, if fit occasion be offered; but why do you come upon me in such haste? is it because (Nurse) I should come over you at leisure?

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.L: Come over me, thou knave? what dost thou mean by that?

SP.SPEAKER: Corbulo.
SP.L: Only this, if you will come off, I will come on.

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.P: My Lord hath strangers to night: you must make ready the Parlour, a table and lights; nay when, I say?

SP.SPEAKER: Corbulo.
SP.P: Me thinks you should rather wish for a bed then for a board, for darkness then for lights; yet I must confess you have been a light woman in your time: but now.

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.L: But now? what now, you knave?

SP.SPEAKER: Corbulo.
SP.L: But now I'l go fetch the table and some lights presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: Some lights to usher in these Gentlemen,
Clear all the roomes without there. Sit, pray sit.
None interrupt our conference.
Ha, whose that?

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse
SP.L: My most—child, if it please you.

SP.SPEAKER: Numitor.
SP.L: Fair Virginia, you are welcome.
The rest forbear us till we call. Sweet cozen,
our business, and the cause of our discourse
admits you to this Councel. Take your place.
Ieilius we are private, now proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Then thus; Lord Appius doth intend me wrong,
and under his smooth calmnesse cloaks a tempest,
that will ere long break out in violence
on me and on my fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: My good cozen,
you are young, and youth breeds rashness. Can I think
Lord Appius will do wrong, who is all Justice,
the most austere and upright Censurer
that ever sate upon the awful Bench?

SP.SPEAKER: Valer.
SP.L: Icilius, you are neer to me in blood,
and I esteem your safety as mine owne.
If you will needs wage eminence and state,
Chuse out a weaker opposite, not one
that in his arm bears all the strength of Rome.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: Besides Icilius,
know you the danger what it is to scandal
one of his place and sway?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: I know it kinsmen, yet this popular Greatness
can be no bug-bear to affright mine innocence.
No his smooth crest hath cast a palped film
over Romes eyes. He juggles, a plain Juggler.
Lord Appius is no lesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: Nay, then Cozen,
you are too harsh, and I must hear no more.
It ill becomes my place and gravity,
to lend a face to such reproachful terms
'gainst one of his high presence.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Sit, pray sit.
to see me draw his picture 'fore your eyes,
to make this man seem monstrous, and this god
Rome so adores, a divel, a plain divel.
This Lord, this Judg, this Appius, that professeth
to all the world a vestal chastity,
is an incontinent, loose Leacher growne.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: Fy cozen.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Nay 'tis true. Daily and hourely
he tempts this blushing Virgin with large promises,
with melting words and Presents of high rate,
to be the stale to his unchaste desires.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: Is't possible?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Possible?
'Tis actual Truth, I pray but ask your Neece.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Most true, I am extremely tyr'd and wearied
with messages and tokens of his love;
no answer, no repulse will satisfie
the tediousness of his importunate suit.
And whilst I could with modesty and honour,
without the danger of reproach and shame,
I kept it secret from Icilius;
but when I saw their boldness found no limit,
and they from fair intreaty grew to threats,
I told him all.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: True: understanding which
to him I went.

SP.SPEAKER: Valer.
SP.L: To Appius?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: To that Gyant,
the high Colossus that bestrides us all;
I went to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Horatio.
SP.L: How did you bear your self?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Like Appius, at the first, dissemblingly,
but when I saw the coast clear, all withdrawn,
and none but we two in the Lobby, then
I drew my Poinyard, took him by the throat,
and when he would have clamor'd, threatned death,
unlesse he would with paence hear me out.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: Did he, Icilius?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: I made him that he durst not squeake,
not move an eye, not draw a breath too loud,
nor stir a fingar.

SP.SPEAKER: Horatio.
SP.L: What succeeded then?

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: Keep fast the door there: Sweet Couz not too loud.
What then succeeded?

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: Why, I told him all,
gave him his due, call'd him lascivious Judge,
(a thousand things which I have now forgot)
shewd him his hand a witnesse 'gainst himself,
and every thing with such known circumstance,
that he might well excuse, but not deny.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: How parted you?

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: Why Friends, in outward shew.
But I perceiv'd his heart: that Hypocrite
was born to gull Rome, and deceive us all.
He swore to me quite to abjure her love;
yet ere my self could reach Virginia's chamber,
one was before me with regreets from him,
I know his hand. Th' intent of this our meeting
was to intreat your counsell and advice:
The good old man her Father is from home,
I think it good that she now in his absence
should lodg in secret with some private friend,
where Appius nor his Lictors, those blood-hounds
can hunt her out. You are her unkle Sir,
I pray counsell the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: To oppose our selves
now in this heat against so great a man,
might in my judgment to our selves bring danger,
and to my Neece no safety. If we fall
she cannot stand; lets then preserve our selves
until her father be discharg'd the Camp.

SP.SPEAKER: Valer.
SP.L: And good Icilius, for your private ends,
and the dear safety of your friends and kindred,
against that Statist, spare to use your spleen.

SP.SPEAKER: Iicil.
SP.L: I will be sway'd by you. My Lords, 'tis late,
and time to break up conference. Noble Uncle
I am your growing Debtor.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: Lights without there.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: I will conduct Virginia to her lodging.
Good night to all at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: The Gods of Rome protect you all, and then
we need not fear the envious rage of men.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius. and Lictors
SP.L: bestow your selves in some close shops,
about the forum, till you have the sight
of faire Virginia, for I understand
this present morning shee'l come forth to buy
some necessaries at the Sempsters shops:
how ere accompanied be it your care
to sease her at our action. Good my friends,
disperse your selves, and keep a carefull watch.
'Tis strange that Ladies will not pay their debts.
'It were strange indeed, if that our Romane Knights.
would give them good example and pay theirs.
The Calender that we Lictors goe by, is all dog dayes.
Right, our common hunt is still to dog unthrifts.
And whats your book of common-prayer?

SP.P: Faith onely for the increase of riotous young Gentlemen i'th' countrey, and banquerouts i'th' City.

SP.L: I know no man more valiant then we are, for wee
back Knights and Gentlemen daily.

SP.P: Right, we have them by the back hourely: your French flye ap∣plied to the nape of the neck for the French Rheume, is not so sore a drawer as a Lictor.

Some say that if a little timbred fellow would juste a great lo∣gerhead, let him be sure to lay him i'th' kennell; but when we shoulder a Knight, or a Knights fellow, we make him more sure, for we ken∣nell him i'th' counter.

SP.L: Come, lets about our businesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: You are growne wondrous amorous of late,
why doe you looke back so often?

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.L: Madam, I goe as a Frenchman rides, all upon one buttock.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: And what's the reason?

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.P: Your Ladiship never saw a Monky in all your life time have a clog at's taile, but hee's still looking back to see what the devil 'tis that followes him.

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.L: Very good, we are your clogs then.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Your crest is growne regardant; here's the beauty▪
that makes your eyes forgetfull of their way.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.L: Beauty? O the gods! Madam I cannot indure her com-

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.L: Why sir, what's my complexion? (plexion.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.L: Thy complexion is just between a moore & a french woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: But she hath a matchlesse eye sir,

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.L: True, her eyes are not right matches, besides she is a widow.

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.L: What then, I pray you?

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.P: Of all waters I would not have my beefe powder'd with a widowes teares.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Why, I beseech you?

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: O they are too fresh Madam, assure your selfe they will not last for the death of fourteen husbands above a day and a quar∣ter; besides, if a man come a wooing to a widow, and invite her to a banquet contrary to the old rule, she will sooner fill her eye then her belly. Besides that, if he looke into her estate, first, look you, Here are foure fingers, first the charge of her husbands funerall, next debts, and legacies, and lastly the reversion; now take away debts and lega∣cies, and what remaines for her second husband?

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.L: I would some of the Tribe heard you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clewn.
SP.P: There's a certaine fish, that as the learned divulge, is call'd a sharke. Now this fish can never feede while he swims upon's bel∣ly, marry when he lies upon his back, oh he takes it at pleasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Well sir, about your businesse, make provision
of those things I directed.

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.P: Sweet Lady, these eyes shall be the clarks of the kitchin for your belly; but I can assure you Woodcocks will be hard to be spoke with, for there's a great feast towards.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: You are very pleasant.

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.P: And fresh cod is taken down thick and threefold, women without great bellies goe together by the ears for't, and such a num∣ber of sweet tooth'd caers in the market, not a calves head to be got for love or money; Muttons mutton now.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Why, was it not so ever?

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.P: No Madam, the sinners i'th' Suburbs had almost tane the me quite away from't, 'twas so cheap and common: but now 'tis at a sweet reckoning, the Terme time is the muttonmonger in the whole calender.

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.L: Doe your Lawyers eat any sallet with their mutton.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Yes, the younger revellers use capers to their mutton, so long till with their shuffling and cutting some of them be out at heeles againe. A bountifull minde and a full purse ever attend your Ladi∣ship.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: O I thank you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clo.
SP.L: See, yon's the Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.P: I will buy up for your Ladiship all the young cuckoes in the market.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: What to doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Clown.
SP.P: O 'tis the most deliatest dish Ile assure you, and newest in fash on: not a great feast in all Rome without a cuckoe.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodi.
SP.L: Virginia. Virg. Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodi.
SP.L: Mistris you doe not know me,
yet we must be acquainted: follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: You doe salute me strangely. Follow you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Doe you hear sir, me thinks you have followers enough. Many Gentlemen that I know, would not have so many tall followers as you have for the price often geldings, I'le assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: Come, will you goe?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Whither? by what command?

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: By warrant of these men, and priviledge
I hold even on thy life. Comeye proud dame,
you are not what you seeme.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Uncivill sir,
what makes you thus familiar and thus bold?
Unhand me villaine.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: What Mistris, to your Lord?
he that can set the raso to your throate,
and punish you as freely as the gods,
no man to aske the cause? Thou art my slave,
and here I sease what's mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Ignoble villaine,
I am as free as the best King or Consull
since Romulus. What dost thou meane? Unhand me.
Give notice to my uncle and Icilius,
what violence is offer'd me▪ Clod. Doe, doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Clow.
SP.P: Doe you presse women for diers, or do you beg women, instead of other commodities; to keep your hands in e? By this light if thou hast any eares on thy head, as it is a question, I'le make my Lord pull you out by th' eares, though you take a Castle.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: Come, will you goe along?

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.P: Whither should she goe sir? here's pulling and haling a poore Gentlewoman.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: Hold you your prating reverence, the whip
shall cease on you for your smooth cozenage.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Are not you servant to Lord Appius.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: How ere I am your Lord, and will approve it
'fore all the Senate.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Thou wilt prove thy selfe
the cursed pander for anothers lust,
and this your plot shall burst about your Ears
like thunderbots.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodi.
SP.L: Hold you that confidence,
first I will you by co of l,
And then I'le alke with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: How now, faire

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: How now, Gen?
What's the offence of faire Virginia,
you bend your weapons on us?

SP.SPEAKER: Lictor.
SP.L: Sir stand back, we fear a rescue.

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: There's no need of feare,
where there's no cause of rescue: what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: O my Icilius! Your incredulity
hath quite undone me, I am now no more
Virginius daughter, so this villaine urges;
But publish't for his bond woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: How's this?

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: 'Tis true my Lord,
and I will take my right by course of Law.

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: Villaines set her free,
or by the power of all our Romane gods,
I'le give that just revenge unto my rage
which should be given to Justice. Bondwoman?

SP.SPEAKER: Clodi.
SP.L: Sir, we doe not come to fight, wee'le deale
By course of Law. My Lord we fear a rescue.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: A rescue? never fear't, here's none in presence
but civill men. My Lord, I am glad to see you.
Noble Icilius, we shall ever love you.
Now Gentlemen reach your Petitions.

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: My Lord, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Worthy Icilius, if you have any businesse defer't
untill tomorrow, or the afternoone,
I shall be proud to pleasure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: The Fox is earth't, my Lord you cannot winde him yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Stooles for my noble friends.—I pray you sit

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: May it please your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Why uncivill sir?
have I not beg'd for bearance of my best
and dearest friends, and must you trouble me?

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: My Lord, I must be heard, and will be heard,
were all the gods in Parliament, I'de burst
their silence with my importunity,
but they should heare me.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: The fellow's mad;
we have no leasure now to heare you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: Hast now no leasure to heare just complaints?
Resigne thy place O Appius, that some other
may doe me Justice then.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Wee'l hear't to morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: O my Lord,
Deny me Justice absolutely, rather
them feed me with delayes.

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: Good my Lord hear him,
and wonder when you heare him, that a case
so full of vile Imposture, should desire
to be unfoulded.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: I my Lord, 'tis true,
the Imposture is on their parts.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Hold your prating,
away with him to prison, clamorous fellow.
Suspect you our uprightnesse?

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: No my Lord:
but I have mighty Enemies, my Lord,
will overflow my cause. See, here I hold
my bondwoman that brags her selfe to be
descended of a noble family.
My purse is too scant to wage Law with them,
I am infor't be mine own advocate,
not one will pleade for me. Now if your Lordship
will doe me justice so, if not then know
high hills are safe, when seas poore dales or▪ eflow.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Sirra, I think it fit to let you know,
e're you proceed in this your subtle suite,
what penalty and danger you acrne,
if you be found to double. Here's a virgin
famous by birth, by education noble,
and she forsooth, haply but to draw
some piece of money from her worthy father,
must needs be challeng'd for a bondwoman.
Sirra take heed, and well bethink your selfe,
I'le make you a president to all the world,
If I but finde you tripping.

SP.SPEAKER: Clodius.
SP.L: Doe it freely.
and view on that condition these just proofes.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Is that the Virgins nurse.

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.P: He milc Nurse my Lord, I had a sore hand with her for a year and a quarter, I have had somewhat to doe with her since too, for the poore Gentlewoman hath been so troubled with the green sicknesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: I pray thee Nurse intreat Sertorius
to come and speak with me.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Here is strange circumstance, view it my Lord,
if he should prove this, it would make Virginius
think he were wronged.

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: There is a devilish cunning
exprest in this black forgerie.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Icilius and Virginia, pray come near,
compound with this base fellow. You were better
disburse some trifle then to undergo
the question of her freedome.

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: O my Lord!
she were not worth a handfull of a bride,
if she did need a bribe.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Nay, take your course,
I onely give you my opinion,
I aske no fee for't. Do you know this fellow?

SP.SPEAKER: Virginia.
SP.L: Yes my Lord, he's your servant.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Y'are i'th' right:
But will you truly know his character?
he was at first a pettie Notary,
a fellow that being trusted with large summes
of honest Citizens, to be imploy'd
i'th' trade of usury; this Gentleman,
couching his credit like a tilting staffe
most cunningly it brake, and at one course
he ran away with thirty thousand pound,
returning to the City seven year after,
having compounded with his creditors
for the third moity, he buyes an office
belonging to our place, depends on us,
in which the oppression and vile injuries
he hath done poore suters, they have cause to rue,
and I to pity: he hath sold his smiles
for silver, but his promises for gold,
his delayes have undone men.
The plague that in some foulded cloud remaines,
the bright Sun soone disperseth; but observe,
when black infection in some dunghill lies,
there's worke for bells and graves, if it doe rise.

SP.SPEAKER: Numitor.
SP.L: He was an ill prop to your house, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Tis true my Lord, but we that have such servants,
are like to Cuccolds that have riotous wives,
we are the last that know it: this is it
makes noblemen suspected to have done ill,
when the oppression lies in their proud followers.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: My Lord, it was some soothing sicophant,
some base detracting Rascal that hath spread
this falsehood in your ears.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Peace Impudence, did I not yester day, no longer since
surprize thee in thy Study counterfeiting.
our hand?

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: 'Tis true, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Being subscribed
unto a Letter fill'd with amorous stuff
unto this Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: I have askt your pardon,
and gave you reason why I was so bold
to use that forgery.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Did you receive it?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: I did my Lord, and I can shew your Lordship
a packet of such Letters.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Now by the Gods,
I'l make you rue it. I beseech you Sir,
show them the reason mov'd you counterfeit
our Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: Sir, I had no other colour.
to come to speak with her.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: A goodly reason!
Did you until this hour acquaint the Lady
with your intended suit?

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: At several times,
and would have drawn her by some private course
to have compounded for her liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Now by a Virgins honour and true birth,
'tis false, my Lord, I never had a dream
so terrible as is this monstrous divel.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Well Sir, referring my particular wrong
to a particular censure, I would know
what is your suit?

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: My Lord, a speedy tryal.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: You shall obtain't with all severity,
I will not give you longer time to dream
upon new slights to cloak your forgery,
Observe you this Camelion, my Lords.
Ile make him change his colour presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: My Lord, although th' uprightness of our cause
needs no delayes, yet for the satisfaction
of old Virginius, let him be present
when we shall crave a tryal.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Sir it needs not:
Who stands for father of the Innocent,
if not the Judg? Ile save the poor old man
that needless travel.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: With your favour Sir,
we must intreat some respit in a business
so needful of his presence.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: I do protest,
you wrong your selves thus to importune it.
Well, let it be to morrow, I'l not sleep
till I have made this thicket a smooth plain,
and giv'n you your true honor back again.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: My Lord, the distance 'twixt the Camp and us
cannot be measured in so short a time.
Let us have four dayes respit.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: You are unwise;
rumor by that time will have fully spred
the scandal, which being ended in one hour
will turn to air: To morrow is the Tryal,
in the mean time, let all contented thoughts
attend you.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: My Lord, you deal unjustly
thus to dismiss her; this is that they seek for,
before to morrow they'l convey her hence
where my claim shall not seise her.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Cunning knave,
You would have bond for her appearance? say.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: I think the motions honest.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Very good.
Icilius shall engage his honoured word
for her appearance.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: As you please, my Lord,
But it were, fitting her old Uucle there
were jointly bound with him.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Well Sir, your pleasure
shall have satiety. You'l take our word
for her appearance; will you not Sir, I pray?

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: Most willingly my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Then Sir you have it,
and i'th' mean time I'l take the honoured Lady
into my guardianship, and by my life,
I'l use her in all kindness as my wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Now by the Gods you shall not.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Shall not, what?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Not use her as your wife Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: O my Lord, I spake it from my heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: I very likely.
She is a Virgin Sir, and must not lye
under a mans forth coming; do you mark?
not under your forth coming, leacherous Appius.

SP.SPEAKER: Appi.
SP.L: Mistake me not, my Lord: Our Secretary,
Take bonds for the appearance of this Lady.
And now to you sir, you that were my servant,
I here casheire you; never shalt thou shrowde
thy villanies under our noble roofe,
nor scape the whip, or the fell hangmans book
by warrant of our favour.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: So my Lord,
I am more free to serve the Gods, I hope,
now I have lost your service.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Harke you sirra,
who shall give bonds for your appearance, ha?
to justifie your claim?

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: I have none, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Away, commit him prisoner to his chamber:
I'le keep you safe from starting.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: Why my Lord?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Away, I wil not hear you.
A Judges heart here in the midst must stand,
and move not a haires bredth to either hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: O were thy heart but of the self same piece
thy tongue is, Appius; how blest were Rome!

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Post to the campe Sertorius, thou hast heard
th'effect of all, relate it to Virginius.
I pray thee use thy ablest horsemanship,
for it concerns us near.

SP.SPEAKER: Serto.
SP.L: I goe my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Sure all this is damn'd cunning.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: O my Lord,
seamen in tempests shun the flattering shore,
to bear full sails upon't were danger more.
So men o're born with greatness stil hold dread,
false seeming friends that on their bosomes spread:
for this is a safe truth which never varies,
He that strikes all his sailes seldome miscarries.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Must we be slaves both to a tyrants will,
and confounding ignorance at once?
Where are we, in a mist, or is this hell?
I have seen as great as the proud Judge have fell:
the bending Willow yeilding to each wind,
shall keep his rooting firme, when the proud Oak.
braving the storme, presuming on his root,
shall have his body rent from head to foote;
Let us expect the worst that may befal,
and with a noble confidence beare all.

SP.STAGE: Enter Appius, Clodius, and a servant.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Here, bear this packet to Minutius,
and privately deliver't, make as much speed
as if thy father were deceas'di'th' Camp,
and that thou went'st to take th'Administration
of what he left thee. Fly.

SP.SPEAKER: Serv.
SP.L: I go my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: O my trusty Clodius.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: My dear Lord,
let me adore your divine policy.
You have poison'd them with sweet meats, you have my Lord.
But what contain those Letters?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Much importance.
Minutius is commanded by that packet
to hold Virginius prisoner in the Camp
on some suspect of Treason.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: But my Lord, how will you answer this?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Tush, any fault
or shadow of a Crime will be sufficient
for his committing: thus when he is absent
we shall in a more calm and friendly sea
sail to our purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: Mercury himself
could not direct more safely.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: O my Clodius,
Observe this rule, one ill must cure another;
as Aconium a strong poison, brings
a present cure against all Serpents stings.
In high attempts, the soul hath infinite eyes,
and 'tis necessity makes men most wise.
Should I miscarry in this desperate plot,
this of my fate in after times be spoken,
I'l break that with my weight on which I am broken.
SP.STAGE: Enter Two Serving men at one door, at the other Corbulo the Clowne melancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Serving.
SP.P: Why how now Corbulo? thou wast not wont to be of this sad temper. What's the matter now?

SP.SPEAKER: Corb.
SP.P: Times change, and seasons alter, some men are born to the Bench, and some to the halter. What do you think now that I am?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Serving.
SP.L: I think thee to be Virginia's man, and Corbulo.

SP.SPEAKER: Corb.
SP.P: No, no such matter: ghess again, tell me but what I am, or what manner of fellow you imagine me to be?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Serving.
SP.L: I take thee to be an honest good, fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Corb.
SP.L: Wide of the ow hand stil Corbulo is no such man.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Serving.
SP.L: What art thou then?

SP.SPEAKER: Corb.
SP.P: Listen, and I'l describe my self to you: I am something better then a Knave, and yet come shor of being an honest man; and though I can sing a ble, yetm accounted b one of the base, being indeed, and a the ca stands with me at this present, in∣feriour to a rogue, and three degrees worse then a Rascal.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Serving.
SP.L: How comes this to passe?

SP.SPEAKER: Corb.
SP.P: Only by my services successe. Take heed whom you serve. Oh you serving Creatures; for this is all I have got by serving my Lady Virginia.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Serving.
SP.L: Why, what of her?

SP.SPEAKER: Corb.
SP.P: She is not the woman you take hee to be; for though she have borrowed no money, yet she entered into bonds; and though you may think her a woman not sufficient, yet 'tis very like her bond will be taken. The truth challenged to be a bond woman; now if she be a bond woman and a slave, and I her servant and Vassal, what did you take me to be? I am an A, a Coat, a worm, a Wood∣cock amongst birds, a Hodmondd amongst flies, amongst Cus a trindle tale, and amongst fishes a poor Ipèr; but amongst Serving men worse, worse then the mans man to the under Yeomen Few∣rer.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Serving.
SP.P: But is it possible, thy Lady is challenged to be a slave? What witness have they?

SP.SPEAKER: Corb.
SP.P: Witness these Fountains, these Flood-gates, these Well∣springs: the poor Gentlewoman was Arrested in the open Market; I offered, I offered to bail her; (though she was) I could not be taken. The grief hath gone so ar my heart, that I be made free, I shall never be mine own man. The Lord Appius hath com∣mitted her to Ward, and it is thought she shall neither lye on the Knight side, not in the Troping Ward, for if he may have his will of her, he means to put in the Hole. His Warrant hath be out for her, but how the case stands with him, or how matters will be taken up with her, s yet uncertain.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Serving.
SP.L: When shall the Tryal be?

SP.SPEAKER: Corb.
SP.P: I take it to be as soon as the morning is brought a bed of a new son and

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Serving.
SP.L: And vvhen is that▪

SP.SPEAKER: Corb.
SP.P: to , every morning you knovv brings forth a nevv n, b they short liv'd, for every night shee drovvns them in the Western ea. But hese , as too high for your dll app . Shall you at the Tryal to morrow?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Serving.
SP.L: By lp e there.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Serving.
SP.L: And I, if I li▪

SP.SPEAKER: Corb.
SP.P: And I, if I dye for : Here's my hand I'l meet you. It is thought my old master will be there at the Bar; for though all the timber of his house yet stand, yet my Lord Numitorius hath sent one of his Posts to the Camp to bid him spur cut and come to the sen∣tence. Oh we have a house at home as heavy as if it were covered with lead. But you will remember to be there.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Serving.
SP.L: And not to fail.

SP.SPEAKER: Corb.
SP.P: If I chance to meet you there, and that the Case go against us, I will give you a quart, not of Wine, but of Tears; for instead of a new Role, I purpose to break my Fast with sops of sorrow.

SP.STAGE: Enter Virginius like a slave, Numitorius, Icilius, Valerius, Horatio Virginia like a slave, Julla, Calphurina, Nurse.

SP.SPEAKER: Virginius.
SP.L: THanks to my noble friends, itnow appears
that you have rather lov'd me then my fortune,
for that's near shipwrackt: chance you see still ranges,
and this short dance of life is full of changes.
Appius! how hollow that name founds, how dreadful?
It is a question, whether the proud Leacher
will view us to our merit; for they say,
his memory to vertue and good men
is still carousing Leth. O the Gods,
not with more terror do the souls in hell
appear before the seat of Rhadamant,
then the poor Clyent yonder.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: O Virginius.
Why do you wear this habit? it ill fits
your noble person, or this reverend place.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Thats true, old man, but it well fits the case
thats now in question. If with form and shew
they prove her slaved, all freedome I'le forgo.

SP.SPEAKER: Icilius.
SP.L: Noble Virginius,
put out a bold and confident defence:
search the Imposture, like a cunning Tryer,
false meals bear the touch, but brook not fire:
their brittleness betrayes them; let your breath
discover as much shame in them, as death
did ever draw from Offenders. Let your truth
nobly supported, void of fear or art,
welcome what ever comes with a great heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Virginius.
SP.L: Now by the Gods, I thank thee noble youth.
I never fear'd in a besieged Town
Mines or great Engines like you Lawyers Gown.

SP.SPEAKER: Virginia.
SP.L: O my dear Lord and father, once you gave me
a noble freedom, do not see it lost
without a forfeit; take the life you gave me
and sacrifice it rather to the gods
then to a villains Lust. Happy the Wretch
who born in bondage lives and dies a slave,
and sees no lustful projects bent upon her,
and neither knowes the life nor death of honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil:
SP.L: We have neither Justice, no nor violence,
which should reform corruption sufficient
to cross their black premeditated doom.
Appius will seize her, all the fire in hell
is leapt into his bosom.

SP.SPEAKER: Virginius.
SP.L: O you Gods,
extinguish it with your compassionate tears,
although you make a second deluge spread,
and swell more high then Tenerif's high head.
Have not the Wars heapt snow sufficient
upon this aged head, but they will stil
pile winter upon winter?
SP.STAGE: Enter Appius, Oppius, Clodius, six Senators, Lictors.

SP.SPEAKER: Appius.
SP.L: Is he come? say.
Now by my life I'l quit the General.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: Your reverence to the Judge, good brother.

SP.SPEAKER: Virginius.
SP.L: Yes Sir, I have learnt my complement thus,
Blest mean estates who stand in fear of many,
and great are curst for that they far not any.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: What is Virginius come?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: I am here my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Where is your daughter?

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: Here my reverend Lord.
Your habit shewes you strangely.

SP.SPEAKER: Virginia.
SP.L: O 'tis fit,
it sutes both time and cause. Pray pardon it,

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Where is your Advocate?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: I have none my Lord.
Truth needs no Advocate, the unjust Cause
buyes up the tongues that travel with applause
in these your thronged Courts. I want not any,
and count him the most wretched that needs many.

SP.SPEAKER: Orator.
SP.L: May it please your reverend Lordships?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: What are you Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: Of counsel with my Clyent Marcus Clodius.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: My Lord, I undertake a desperate combat
to cope with this most eloquent Lawyer:
I have no skill i'th' weapon, good my Lord;
I mean, I am not travell'd in your Lawes.
My suit is therefore by your special goodness
they be not wrested against me.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: O Virginius, the gods defend they should.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Your humble servant shall ever pray for you.
Thus shall your glory be above your place,
or those high titles which you hold in Court,
for they dy blest that dy in good report.
Now Sir I stand you.

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: Then have at you Sir.
May it please your Lordships, here is such a Case
so full of subtilty, and as it were,
so far benighted in an ignorant mist,
that though my reading be sufficient,
my practice more, I never was intangled
in the like pursenet. Here is one that claimes
this woman for his daughter. Heres another
affirms she is his Bond-slave. Now the Question
(with favour of the Bench) I shall make plain
in two words only without circumstance.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Fall to your proofs.

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: Where are our papers.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: Here Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: Where Sir? I vow y'are the most tedious Clyent.
Now we come to't my Lord. Thus stands the Case,
the Law is clear on our sides. Hold your prating.
That honourable Lord Virginius,
having been married about fifteen year,
