and Issuless, this Virgins politick mother
Seeing the Land was likely to descend
to Numitorius. I pray Sir listen.
You my Lord Numitorius attend,
we are on your side. Old Virginius
imployed in forraign wars, she se him
she was with child; observe it, I beseech you,
and note the trick of a deceitful woman:
she in the mean time fai the passions
of a great bllyed woman, counters
their passions and their and verily
all Rome held this for no posterous stuff.
What's to be done now? heres a rumor spread
of a young Heir, gods bless it, and belly
bumbasted with a cushion: but their wants,
(What wants there?) nothing but a pretty babe,
bought with some piece of mony, where it skils not,
to furnish this supposed lying in.

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse:
SP.L: I protest my Lord, the fellow i'th' night cap
hath not spoke one true word yet.

SP.SPEAKER: App
SP.L: Hold you your prating woman til you are call'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: 'Tis purchast. Where? From this mans bond-woman
The mony paid. What was the sum of mony?

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: A thousand Drachmas.

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: Good, a thousand Drachmas.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Where is that bond-woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: She's dead, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: O dead, that makes your Cause suspicious.

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: But here's her deposition on her death bed,
with other testimony to confirm
what we have said is true. Wilt please your Lordship
take pains to view these writings. Here, my Lord,
we shall not need to hold your Lordships long,
we'l make short work on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: By your favour.
If that your claim be just, how happens it
that you have discontinued it the space
of fourteen years?

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: I shall resolve your Lordship.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: I vow this is a practis'd Dialogue:
comes it not rarely off?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Peace, give them leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: 'Tis very true, this Gentleman at first
thought to conceal this accident, and did so,
only reveal'd his knowledg to the mother
of this fair bond-woman, who bought his silence
during her life time with great sums of Coyn.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Where are your proofs of that?

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: Here, my good Lord, with depositions likewi.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Well, go on.

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: For your question
of discontinuance. Put case my slave
run away from me, dwell in some near City
the space of twenty years, and there grow rich,
it is in my discretion, by your favor,
to seize him when I please.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: That's very true.

SP.SPEAKER: Virginia.
SP.L: Cast not your nobler beams, you reverend Judges
on such a putrified dunghil.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: By your favour, you shall be heard anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: My Lords, believe not this spruce Orator.
Had I but fee'd him first, he would have told
as smooth a tale on our side.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Give us leave.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: He deals in formal glosses, cunning showes,
and cares not greatly which way the Case goes;
Examine I beseech you this old woman,
who is the truest witness of her birth.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Soft you, is she your only witness?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: She is, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Why, is it possible
such a great Lady in her time of child birth,
should have no other Witness but a Nurse?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: For ought I know the rest are dead, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Dead? no my Lord, belike they were of counsel
with your deceased Lady, and so sham'd
twice to give colour to so vile an act.
Thou Nurse observe me, thy offence already
doth merit punishment beyond our censure,
pull not more whips upon thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Nurse.
SP.L: I defie your whips, my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Command her silence Lictors.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: O injustice! you frown away my Witness;
Is this Law? is this uprightness?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Have you viewed the Writings?
This is a trick to make our slaves our heirs
beyond prevention.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Appius, wilt thou hear me?
You have standred a sweet Lady that now sleeps
in a most noble Monument. Observe me,
I would have ta'ne her simple word to gage
before his soul or thine.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: That makes thee wretched.
Old man, I am sorry for thee that thy love,
by custome is growne natural, which by nature
should be an absolute loathing. Note the Sparrow,
that having hatch'd a Cucko, when it sees
her brood a Monster to her proper kind,
forsakes it, and with more fear shuns the nest,
then she had care i'th' Spring to have it drest.
cast thy affection then behind thy back, and think.—

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: Be wise, take counsel of your friends.
You have many souldiers in their time of service
father strange children.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: True: and Pleaders too,
when they are sent to visit Provinces.
You my most neat and cunning Orator,
whose tongue is Quick-silver, Pray thee good Janus
look not so many several wayes at once,
but go to th' point.

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: I will, and keep you out
at points end, though I am no souldier.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: First the oath of the deceased bond-woman.

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: A very vertuous Matron.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Join'd with the testimony of Clodius.

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: A most approved honest Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Besides six other honest Gentlemen.

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.P: All Knights, and there's no question but their oaths will go for currant.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: See my reverend Lords,
and wonder at a Case so evident.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: My Lord, I knew it.

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: Observe my Lord how their own Policy
confounds them. Had your Lordship yesterday
proceeded as 'twas fit, to a just sentence,
the Aparrel and the Jewels that she wore,
more worth then all her Tribe, had then been due
unto our Client: now to cosen him
of such a forfeit, see they bring the maid
in her most proper habit, bond-slave like,
and they will save by th' hand too. Please your Lordships,
I crave a sentence.

SP.SPEAKER: Virginius. Appius. Virginia.
SP.L: My Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Lord Appius.

SP.SPEAKER: Virginius.
SP.L: Now by the Gods here's juggling.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: Who cannot counterfeit a dead mans hand?

SP.SPEAKER: Virginius.
SP.L: Or hire some villain to swear forgeies?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Clodius was brought up in your house my Lord,
and that's suspicious.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: How is't probable,
that our wife being present at the child-birth,
whom this did nearest concern, should nere reveal it?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Or if ours dealt thus cunningly, how haps it
her policy, as you term it, did not rather
provide an Issue male to chear the father?

SP.SPEAKER: Orat.
SP.L: I'l answer each particular.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: It needs not,
Heres witness, most sufficient witness.
Think you, my Lord, our Lawes are writ in snow,
and that your breath can melt them?

SP.SPEAKER: Virginius.
SP.L: No my Lord,
We have not such hot livers: Mark you that?

SP.SPEAKER: Virginia.
SP.L: Remember yet the Gods, O Appius,
who have no part in this. Thy violent Lust
shall like the biting of the invenom'd Aspick,
steal thee to hell. So subtil are thy evils,
in life they'l seem good Angels, in death divels.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Observe you not this scandal?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Sir, 'Tis none.
I'l show thy Letters full of violent Lust
sent to this Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Wilt thou breath a lye
'fore such a reverend Audience?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: That place
is sanctuary to thee. Lye? see here they are.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: My Lords, these are but dilatory shifts.
Sirrah I know you to the very heart,
and I'l observe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Do but do it with Justice.
Clear thy self first, O Appius, ere thou judg
our imperfections rashly, for we wot
the Office of a Justice is perverted quite
when one thief hangs another.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Senator.
SP.L: You are too bold.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Lictors take charge of him▪

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: 'Tis very good.
Will no man view these papers? What not one?
Jove thou hast found a Rival upon earth,
his nod strikes all men dumb. My duty to you.
The Ass that carried sis on his back,
thought that the superstitious people kneel'd
to give his dulnesse humble reverence.
If thou thinkst so, proud Judg, I let thee see
I bend low to thy Gown, but not to thee.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: There's one in hold already. Noble youth
fetters grace one being worn for speaking truth;
I'l lye with thee, I swear, though in a dungeon;
the injuries you do us we shall pardon,
but it is just the wrongs which we forgive,
the gods are charg'd therewith to see revenged.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Come, y'are a proud Plebian.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: True my Lord.
Proud in the glory of my Ancestors,
who have continued these eight hundred years:
the Heralds have not knowne you these eight months.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Your madness wrongs you, by my soul I love you.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Thy soul?
O thy opinion old Pythagoras,
Whither, O whither should thy black soul fly,
into what ravenous bird or beast most vile?
only into a weeping Crocodile.
Love me? Thou loy'st me (Appius) as the earth loves rain,
thou fain wouldst swallow me.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Know you the place you speak in?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: I'l speak freely.
Good men too much trusting their innocence
do not betake them to that just defence
which Gods and Nature gave them; but even wink
in the black tempest, and so fondly sink.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Let us proceed to sentence.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Ere you speak
One parting farwel let me borrow of you
to take of my Virginia.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Now my Lords,
we shall have fair confession of the truth.
Pray take your course.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Farewel my sweet Virginia, never, never
shall I taste fruit of the most blessed hope
I had in thee. Let me forget the thought
of thy most pretty infancy, when first
returning from the Wars, I took delight
to rock thee in my Target, when my Girl
would kiss her father in his burganet
of glittering steel hung'bout his armed neck;
and viewing the bright mettal, smile to see
another fair Virginia smile on thee.
When I first taught thee how to go, to speak,
and when my wounds have smarted, I have sung
with an unskilful, yet a willing voice,
to bring my Girl asleep. O my Virginia,
when we begun to be, begun our woes,
increasing still, as dying life still growes.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: This tediousness doth much offend the Court.
Silence: attend her Sentence.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Hold, without Sentence I'l resign her freely,
since you will prove her to be none of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: See, see, how evidently Truth appears.
Receive her Clodius.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Thus I surrender her into the Court
of all the Gods. And see proud Appius see,
although not justly, I have made her free.
And if thy Lust with this Act be not fed,
bury her in thy bowels, now shee's dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: O horrid act!

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Lay hand upon the Murderer.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Oh for a ring of pikes to circle me.
What? have I stood the brunt of thousand enemies
here to be slain by hang-men? No. I'l fly
to safety in the Camp.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Some pursue the villain,
others take up the body. Madness and rage
are still th' Attendants of old doting age.
Is our Hut swept clean?
As I can make it.
'Tis betwixt us two;
but how many think'st thou, bred of Roman blood,
did lodg with us last night?
More I think then the Camp hath enemies,
they are not to be numbred.
Comrague, I fear Appius will doom us to Acteons death,
to be worried by the Cattel that we feed.
How goes the day?
My stomack has struck twelve.
Come see what provant our knapsack yeilds.
This is our store, our Garner.
A smal pitance.
Feeds Appius thus, is this a City feast?
This crust doth taste like date stones, and this thing
if I knew what to call it.
I can tell you: cheese struck in years.
I do not think but this same crust was bak'd
and this cheese frighted out of milk and whey
before we two were souldiers: though it be old
I see 't can crawl; what living things be these
that walk so freely 'tween the ind and pith?
for here's no sap left.
They call them Gentles.
Therefore 'tis thought fit,
that Souldiers by profession Gentlemen
should thus be fed with Gentles. I am stomack sick,
I must have some strong water.
Where will you hav't?
In you green ditch, a place which none can pass
but he must stop his nose, thou know'st it well,
there where the two dead dogs lye.
Yes I know't.
And see the Cat that lyes a distance off
be flead for supper. Though we dine to day
as Dutch men feed their souldiers, we will sup
bravely like Roman Leaguerers.
Sir, the General.
Wee'l give him place,
but tell none of our dainties, lest we have
too many guests to supper.
SP.STAGE: Enter Minutius with his souldiers reading a Letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Most sure 'tis so, it cannot otherwise be,
Either Virginius is degenerate
from the ancient vertues he was wont to boast,
or in some strange displeasure with the Senate;
Why should these letters else from Appius
confine him a close prisoner to the Camp?
and which confirmes his guilt, why should he fly?
needs then must I incur some high displeasure
for negligence to let him thus escape;
which to excuse, and that it may appear
I have no band with him, but am of faction
oppos'd in all things to the least mildeed,
I will casheir him, and his Tribuneship
bestow upon some noble Gentleman
belonging to the Camp. Souldiers and friends,
you that beneath Virginius Colours march,
by strict command from the Decemvirat,
we take you from the charge of him late ,
and his Authority, Command, and Honour
we give this worthy Roman. Know his Colours,
and prove his faithful Souldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Roman.
SP.L: Warlike General,
my courage and my forwardnesse in battel,
shal plead how well I can deserve the title,
to bee a Roman Tribune.
SP.STAGE: Enter the first mutinous Souldier in haste.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Now, the newes?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sould.
SP.L: Virginius in a strange shape of distraction,
enters the Campe, and at his heels a legion
of all estates, growths, ages, and degrees,
with breathlesse paces dog his frighted steps.
It seemes half Roo's unpeopled with a traine
that either for some mischiefe done, pursue him,
or to attend some uncouth novelty.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Some wonder our fear promises. Worthy souldiers,
martial your selves, and entertaine this novel
within a ring of steele: Wall in this portent
with men and harnesse, be it ne're so dreadful.
Hee's entred by the clamour of the camp,
that entertaines him with these ecchoing showts.
Affection that in Souldiers hearts is bred,
survives the wounded, and out lives the dead.
SP.STAGE: Enter Virginius with his knife, that and his arms stript up to the elbowes all bloudy; coming into the midst of the soul∣diers, he makes a stand.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Have I in all this populous Assembly
of souldiers that have prov'd Virginius valour,
one friend? Let him come thrill his partisan
against this brest, that through a large wide wound,
my mighty soule might rush out of this prison
to flie more freely to yon christal pallace,
where honour sits inthronis'd. What, no friend?
Can this great multitude then yeild an enemy
that hates my life? Here let him seise it freely.
What, no man strike? am I so wel beloved?
Minutius then to thee. If in this camp
there lives one man so just to punish sin,
so charitable to redeem from torments
a wretched souldier, at his worthy hand
a death.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: What means Virginius?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: O if the Generals heart be so obdu,
to an old begging souldier, Have I here
no honest Legionary of mine own Troo
at whose bold hand and sword, if not .
I may command a death?

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sould.
SP.L: Alas good Captain.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Virginius, you have no command at all,
your Companies are elsewhere now bestowed.
Besides, we have a Charge to you here.
and make you the Camps prisoner.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: General, thanks.
For thou hast done as much with one harsh word
as I beg'd from their weapons. Thou hast kill'd me
but with a living death.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Besides, I charge you
to speak what means this ugly face of blood,
you put on your distractions? Whats the reason
all Rome pursues you, covering those high ,
as if they dog'd you for some damned act?
What have you done?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: I have plaid the Pacide,
Kill'd mine own child,

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Virginia?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Yes, even she.
These rude hands ript her, and her innocent blood
flow'd above my elbowes.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Kill'd her willingly?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Willingly, with advice, premeditation,
and settled purpose; and see still I wear
her crimson colours, and these withered armes
are dy'd in her heart blood.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Most wretched villain?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: But how? I lov'd her life. Lend me amongst you
one speaking Organ to discourse her death;
It is too harsh an imposition
to lay upon a father. O my Virginia!

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: How agrees this? love her, and murder her?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Yes, Give me but a little leave to
a few red tears, (for souldiers should weep blood)
and I'l agree them well. Attend me all.
Alas, might I have kept her chaste and free,
this life so oft ingag'd for ingrateful Rome,
lay in her bosom. But when I saw her pull'd
by Appius Lictors to be claim'd a slve,
and drag'd unto a publick Sessions house,
divorc'd from her fore Spousals with Icilius,
a noble youth, and made a bond-woman,
inforc'd by violence from her fathers armes
to be a Prostiture and Permour
to the rude twinings of a leacherous Judge;
Then, then, O loving Souldiers, (I'l not deny it)
for 'twas mine honor, my paernal pity,
and the sole act, for which I love my life.
Then lustful Appius, he that swayes the Land,
slew poor Virginia by this fathers hand.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Sould.
SP.L: O villain Appius.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Sold.
SP.L: O noble Virginius.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: To you I appeal, you are my Sentencers:
Did Appius right, or poor Virginius wrong?
Sentence my Fact with a free general tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sold.
SP.L: Appius is the Parricide.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Sold.
SP.L: Virginins guiltless of his daughters death.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: It this be true, Virginius as the moan
of all the Roman fry that followes you
confirmes at large, this cause is to be pityed,
and should not dy revengelesse.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Noble Minutius,
Thou hast a daughter, thou hast a wife too,
so most of yôu have Souldiers. Why might not this
have hapned you? Which of you all, deer friends,
but now, even now, may have your wives deflowred,
your daughters slav'd, and made a Lictors prey?
Think them not safe in Rome, for mine lived there.

SP.SPEAKER: Roman.
SP.L: It is a common cause.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Sold.
SP.L: Appius shall dy for't.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Sold.
SP.L: Lets make Virginius General.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: A General, a General, lets make Virginius General.

SP.SPEAKER: Munit.
SP.L: It shall be so. Virginius take my Charge,
the wrongs are thine, so violent and so weighty
that none but he that lost fo a child,
knowes how to punish. By the Gods of Rome,
Virginius shall succeed my full command.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: What's honor unto me, a weak old man,
weary of life, and covetous of a grave?
I am a dead man now Virginia lives not,
the self same hand that dar'd to save from shame
a child, dares in the father the

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sould.
SP.L: Stay noble General

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: You much for nge, Virginias.
Who, if you dye, will take your ause in hand,
and proscribe Appius, should you pish thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Thou oughtest Minutius. Soldiers, so ought you.
I'm out of fear, my noble wife's expir'd,
My daughter (of blest memory) the object
of Appius lust, lives the Elyan Vestals,
my house yeilds none fit for his Lictors spoil.
You that have wives lodg'd in you prison Rome,
have Lands unried, houses yet ;
your freeborn daughters yet unstrumpeted,
prevent these mischiefs yet while you have time.

SP.SPEAKER: 1. Sold.
SP.L: We will by you our noble General.

SP.SPEAKER: 2. Sold.
SP.L: He that was destin'd to preserve great Rome.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: I accept your ch▪ in hope to guard you all
from my inhumane sufferings. Be my pride
that I have bred a daughter whose chast blood
was spilt for you, and for Romes laing good.

SP.STAGE: Enter Opius, a Senator, and the Advocate.

SP.SPEAKER: Opius.
SP.L: IS Appius then committed?

SP.SPEAKER: Senator.
SP.L: So 'tis .

SP.SPEAKER: Opius.
SP.L: How will you bear you in this turbule state?
You are a Member of that wretched Faction.
I wonder how you scape imprisonment?

SP.SPEAKER: Advocate.
SP.L: Let me alone, I have learnt with the wi Hedog.
to stop my cave that way the pest drives.
Never did Bear-whelp bling down a hill
with more art shrink his head betwixt his clawes
then I will work my safety Appius
is in the sand already up to th' chin,
and shal I hazard landing on that shelf?
Hee's a wise friend that first himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Opius.
SP.L: What is your course, of ?

SP.SPEAKER: Advoc.
SP.L: Marry this
Virginius with his Troops is entering Rome,
and it is like that in the market place
my L. Icilius and himself shall meet.
Now to encounter these, two such great Armies,
where lies my Court of Guard?

SP.SPEAKER: Senat.
SP.L: Why in your heels.
There are strange dogs uncoupled.

SP.SPEAKER: Adv.
SP.L: You are deceiv'd,
I have studied a most eloquent Oration,
that shall applaud their fortune, and distaste
the cruelty of Appius.

SP.SPEAKER: Senat.
SP.L: Very good Sir.
It seems then you will rail upon your Lord,
your late good Benefactor.

SP.SPEAKER: Adv.
SP.L: By the way Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Senat.
SP.L: Protest Virginia was no bond-woman,
and read her noble Pedigree.

SP.SPEAKER: Adv.
SP.L: By the way Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Opius.
SP.L: Could you not by the way too find occasion
to beg Lord Appius Lands?

SP.SPEAKER: Adv.
SP.L: And by the way
perchance I will. For I will gull them all
most palbably.

SP.SPEAKER: Opius.
SP.L: Indeed you have the Art
of flattery.

SP.SPEAKER: Adv.
SP.L: Of Rhetorick you would say.
And I'l begin my smooth Oration thus,
Most learned Captains.

SP.SPEAKER: Senat.
SP.L: Fie, fie, thats horrible, most of your Captains.
are utterly unlearned.

SP.SPEAKER: Adv.
SP.L: Yet I assure you,
most of them know Arithmatick so well,
that in a Muster to preserve dead payes,
they I make twelve stand for twenty.

SP.SPEAKER: Opius.
SP.L: Very good.

SP.SPEAKER: Adv.
SP.L: Then I proceed,
I do applaud your fortunes, and commend
in this your observation, noble shake-rags.
The Helmet shall no more harbour the spider,
but it shall serve to carowse Sack and Sider.
The rest within I'l study.

SP.SPEAKER: Opius.
SP.L: Farewel Proteus,
and I shall wish thy eloquent bravado
may shild thee from the whip and Eastinado.
now in this furious tempest let us glide,
with foulded sails at pleasure of the Tyde.
SP.STAGE: Enter Icilius, Horatio, Valerius, Numitorius (at o door) with Souldiers; Virginius, Minutius, and others at the other doore.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Stand.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Make a stand.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: A prly with Virginius.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: We wil not trust our General 'twixt the Armies,
but upon terms of hostage.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: Well advised!
Nor we our General: who for the leaguer?

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Our selfe.
SP.STAGE: Minutius and Numi∣torius meet embrace, sa∣lute the Generals.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Who for the City?

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: How is it with your sorrow noble brother?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: I am forsaken of the gods, old man.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: Preach not that wretched doctrine to your self,
It wil beget despaire.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: What doe you call
a burning Feaver? Is not that a divel?
It shakes me like an earthquake. Wilt a, wilt a
give me some Wine?

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: O it is hurtful for you!

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Why so? are all things that the appetite
of man doth covet in his perfect'st health,
what ever Art or Nature have invented,
to make the boundlesse wish of man contented,
Are all his poison? Give me the Wine there.—When?
Do you grudge me a poor cup of drink? Say, Say.
Now by the gods, I'll leave enough behind me
to pay my debts, and for the rest, no matter
who scrambles for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: Here my noble brother I
Alas, your hand shakes. I will guide it to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: 'Tis true, it trembles. Welcome thou just palsie,
'twere pity this should doe me longer service,
now it hath slain my daughter. So I thank you;
now I have lost all comforts in the world,
it seems I must a little longer live;
bee't but to serve my belly.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: O my Lord,
this violent Feaver took him late last night,
since when, the cruelty of the disease,
hath drawn him into sundry passions
beyond his wonted temper.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: 'Tis the gods
have powred their Justice on him.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: You are sadly met my Lord.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Would we had met
in a cold grave together two months since,
I should not then have curst you.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Ha! Whats that?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Old man, thou hast shewed thy self a noble Roman,
but an unnatural Father; thou hast turned
my Bridal to a Funeral. What divel
did arme thy fury with the Lions paw,
the Dragons taile, with the Bulls double horne,
the Cormorants beak, the Cockatrices eyes,
the Scorpions teeth? and all these by a father
to be imployed upon his innocent child?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Young man, I love thy true description;
I am happy now, that one beside my selfe,
doth teach me for this act. Yet were I pleased,
I cou'd approve the deed most Just and noble;
and sure posterity, which truely renders
to each man his desert, shal praise me for't.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Come, 'twas unnatural and damnable.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: You need not interrupt me. Here's a fury
wil doe it for you! You are a Roman Knight.
What was your oath when you receiv'd your Knighthood?
a parcel of it is, as I rememember,
rather to die with honour, then to live
in servitude. Had my poor girle been ravish'd,
in her dishonour, and in my sad griefe,
your love and pity quickly had ta'ne end.
Great mens misfortunes thus have ever stood,
they touch none neerly, but their neerest blood.
What do you meane to do? It seems, my Lord,
now you have caught the sword within your hand,
like a madman you'le draw it to offend
those that best love you; and perhaps the counsel
of some loose unthrifts, and vile male contents
hearten you to't: goe to, take your course,
my faction shal not give the least advantage
to murtherers, to banquerouts, or theeves,
to fleece the common Wealth.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Do you term us so?
Shal I reprove your rage, or is't your malice?
He that would tame a Lion, doth not use
the goad or wierd whip, but a sweet voice,
a fearful stroaking, and with food in hand
must ply his wanton hunger.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg:
SP.L: Want of sleep wil do it better then all these, my Lord.
I would not have you wake for others ruine,
lest you turn mad with watching.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: O you gods!
You are now a General; learn to know your place,
and use your noble calling modestly.
Better had Appius been an upright Judg,
and yet an evil man, then honest man,
and yet a dissolute Judg; for all disgrace
lights lesse upon the person, then the place.
You are i'th' City now, where if you raise
but the least uproare, even your Fathers house
shal not be free from ransack. Piteous fires
that chance in Towrs of stone, are not so feared
as those that light in Flax shops; for there's food
for eminent ruin.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: O my noble Lord!
Let not your passion bring a fatal end
to such a good beginning. All the world
shal honour that deed in him, which first
grew to a reconcilement.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Come my Lord,
I love your friendship; yes in sooth I do,
but wil not seale it with that bloody hand.
Joine we our armies. No phantastick copy,
or borrowed President wil I assume
in my revenge. There's hope yet you may live,
to outwear this sorrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: O Impossible.
A minutes joy to me, would quite crosse nature,
as those that long have dwelt in noisome rooms,
swoun presently if they but scent perfumes.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: to th' Senate. Come, no more of this sad tale,
for such a tel-tale may we term our grief,
and doth as 'twere so listen to her own words,
Envious of others sleep, because shee wakes.
I ever would converse with a griev'd person
in a longe journey to beguile the day,
or winter evening to passe time away.
March on, and let proud Appius in our view
like a tree rotted, fall that way he grew.
SP.STAGE: Enter Appius, and Marcus Clodius in prison, fettred and gyved.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: The world is chang'd now. All damnations
seize on the Hydra headed multitude,
that only gape for innovation.
O who would trust a people?

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: Nay, who would not,
rather then one rear'd on a popular suffrage,
whose station's built on Avees and Applause?
There's no firm structure on these airy Bases.
O fie upon such Greatness.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: The same ands
that yesterday to hear me conscionate.
and Orarorize, rung shril Plaudits forth
in sign of grace, now in contempt and scorn
hurry me to this place of darkness.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: Could not their poisons rather spend themselves,
on th' Judges folly, but must it needs stretch
to me his servant, and sweep me along?
Curse on the inconstant rabble.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Grieves it thee
to impart my sad disaster?

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: Marry doth it.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Thou shared'st a fortune with me in my Greatness,
I ha'd thee after when I climb my State,
and shrink'st thou at my ruine?

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: I loved your Greatness,
and would have trac'd you in the golden path
of sweet promotion; but this your decline
sowrs all these hoped sweets.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: 'Tis the world right.
Such gratitude a great man still shall have
that trusts unto a temporizing slave.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: Slave? Good. Which of us two in our dejection
is basest? I am most sure
your loathsome dungeon is as dark as mine,
your conscience for a thousand sentences
wrongly denounc'd, much more opprest then mine.
then which is the most slave▪

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: O double baseness,
to hear a drudg thus with his Lord compare!
Great men disgrac'd, slaves to their servants are.
SP.STAGE: Enter Virginius, Icilius, Minutius, Numitoriut, Horatio, Valerius, Opius with souldiers.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Souldiers, keep a strong guard whilst we survey
our sentenc'd prisoners: And from this deep dungeon
keep off that great concourse, whose violent hands
would ruine this stone building and drag hence
this impious Judg peice▪ meal, to tear his limbs
before the Law convince him.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: See these Monsters,
whose fronts the fair Virginias innocent blood
hath visarded with such black ugliness,
that they are loathsome to all good mens souls.
Speak damn'd Judg how canst thou purge thy self
from Lust and blood?

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: I do confess my self
guilty of both: yet hear me, noble Romans,
Virginius, thou dost but supply my place,
I thine. Fortune hath lift thee to my Chair,
and thrown me headlong to thy pleading bar.
If in mine eminence I was stern to thee;
shunning my rigor, likewise shun my fall.
And being mild where I shewed cruelty,
establish still thy greatness. Make some use
of this my bondage. With indifference
survey me, and compe my yesterday
with this sad hour, my heighth with my decline,
and give them equal ballance.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Ucertain fate, but yesterday his breath
'd Rome, and his least ved frown was death:
I cannot chuse but pity and lament,
So high a rise should have such low discent.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: He's ready to forget his injury.
(Oh too relenting age!) Thinks not Virginius,
if he should pardon Appius this black deed,
and set him once more in the Ivory Chair,
he would be wary to avoid the like,
become a new man, a more upright Judge,
and deserve better of the Common Weal?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: 'Tis like he would.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Nay, if you thus begin,
I'l fetch that shall anatomize his .

SP.SPEAKER: Numit.
SP.L: Virginius, you are oo to
deeds of this nature. You must fashion now
your actions to your place, not to your passion,
severity to such acts is as necessary
as pity to the tears of innocence.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: He speaks but Law and Justice.
Make good the streets, with your best men at arms:
Valerius and Horatio know the reason
of this loud uproar, and confused noise.
Although my heart be melting at the fall
of men in place and Office, we'l be just
to punish murdrous Acts, and censure Lust.

SP.SPEAKER: Valer.
SP.L: Icilius, worthy Lord, bears through the street
the body of Virginia towards this prison;
which when it was discovered to the people,
mov'd such a mournful clamour, that their cryes
pierc'd heaven, and forc'd tears from their sorrowing eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Horat.
SP.L: Here comes Icilius.
SP.STAGE: Enter Icilius with the body of Virginia.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Where was thy pity when thou slewest this maid,
thou wouldst extend to Appius? Pity? See
her wounds still bleeding at the horrid presence
of you stern Murderer, till she find revenge;
nor will these drops stench, or these springs be dry
till theirs be set a bleeding: Shall her soul
(whose essence some suppose lives in the blood)
still labour without rest? Will old Virginius
murder her once again in this delay?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Pause there Icilius.
This sight hath stiffned all my operant powers,
ic'd all my blood, benum'd my motion quite.
I'l powre my soul into my daughters belly,
and with a soldiers tears imbalm her wounds.
My only dear Virginia!

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Leave this passion,
proceed to your just sentence.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: We will. Give me two sword. Appius grasp this,
You Clodius that. You shall be your own hang-men,
do Justice on your selves. You made Virginius.
uce his own blood: lodg'd in his daughters brest,
which your own hands shall act upon your selves.
If you be Romans, and retain their spirits,
redeem a base life with a noble death,
and through your yo ath.

SP.SPEAKER: App.
SP.L: Virginius is a noble Justicer,
had I my crooked paths levell'd by thine.
I had not swayed the ballance. Think not Lords,
but he that had the sit to oppose the Gods,
dares likewise suffer what their powers inflict:
I have not dreaded famine, fire, no strage,
their common vengeance, poison in my cup,
nor dagger in my bosom, the revenge
of private men for private injuries;
nay more then these, not fe'd to commit evil,
and shall I tremble at the punishment?
Now with as much resolved constancy,
as I offended, will I pay the mulct,
and this black stain laid on my family,
then which a nobler hath not place in Rome,
Wash with my blood away. Learn of me Clodius,
I'l teach thee what thou never studiest yet,
thats bravely how to dy. Judges are term'd
the Gods on earth; and such as are corrupt
read me in this my ruine. Those that succeed me
that so offend, thus punish. This the sum of all,
Appius that in'd, by Appius hand shall fall.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: He dyed as boldly as he basely err'd,
and so should every true bred Roman do.
And he whose lise was odious, thus expiring;
in his death forceth pity. Clodius thou
wast follower of his fortunes in his being,
therefore in his not being imitate
his fair example.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: Death is terrible
unto a conscience that's opprest with guilt.
They say there is Elizium and Hel,
the first I have forfeited, the latter fear.
My skin is not sword proof.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Why dost thou pawse?

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: For mercy, mercy I intreat you all.
Is't not sufficient for Virginia slain
that Appius suffered; one of noble blood,
and eminence in place, for a Plebian?
Besides, he was my Lord and might command me:
If I did ought, 'twas by compulsion, Lords,
and therefore I crave mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Shall I doom him?

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: Do, good Icilius.

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Then I sentence thus:
Thou hadst a mercy, most unmeriting slave,
of which thy base birth was not capable,
which we take off by taking thence thy sword.
And note the difference 'twixt a noble strain,
and one bred from the rabble: both alike
da'd to transgresse, but see their odds in death:
Appius dy'd like a Roman Gentleman,
and a man both wayes knowing; but this slave
is only sensible of vitious living,
not apprehensive of a noble death.
Therefore as a base Malefactor (we)
and timerous slave, give him (as he deserves)
unto the common Hangman.

SP.SPEAKER: Clod.
SP.L: What, no mercy?

SP.SPEAKER: Icil.
SP.L: Stop's mouth,
away with him: the life of the Decemviri
expires in them. Rome thou at length art free,
restored unto thine ancient liberty.

SP.SPEAKER: Minut.
SP.L: Of Consu: which bold Iunius Brutus first
begun in Tarquins fall. Virginius you
and young Icilius shall his place succeed,
so by the peoples suffrage 'tis decreed.

SP.SPEAKER: Virg.
SP.L: We martial then our souldiers in that name
of Consuls, honoured with these golden bayes.
Two fair, but Ladies most infortunate,
have in their ruins rais'd declining Rome,
Lucretia and Virginia, both renown'd▪
for chastity. Souldiers and noble Romans
to grace her death, whose life hath freed great Rome,
march with her Course to her sad Funeral Tomb.
